title: 111_hr436
content: The "Certain Estate Tax Relief Act of 2009" repeals certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 related to estate tax and carryover basis. It also includes modifications to the estate tax. The "Certain Estate Tax Relief Act of 2009" modifies the estate tax by excluding $3,500,000 from the applicable credit amount and freezing the maximum estate tax rate at 45 percent. The amendment increases the tentative tax by 5 percent for amounts exceeding $10,000,000, with a limit based on the applicable credit amount and $119,200. Effective after December 31, 2009, for estates and gifts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new valuation rules for certain transfers of nonbusiness assets. This applies to transfers of interests in entities that are not actively traded, where the value of nonbusiness assets is determined as if transferred directly to the transferee without any valuation discount allowed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new valuation rules for certain transfers of nonbusiness assets. Nonbusiness assets are not considered in determining the value of an interest in an entity unless they are used in the active conduct of one or more trades or businesses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new valuation rules for certain transfers of nonbusiness assets. Nonbusiness assets are not considered in determining the value of an interest in an entity unless they are used in the active conduct of one or more trades or businesses. Material participation rules apply, except for farming activities. Working capital assets are exempt from these rules. Passive assets, including cash, stock, debt instruments, and annuities, held for working capital needs are considered used in the active conduct of a trade or business. Passive assets like annuities, real property used in real property trades, assets producing royalty income, commodities, collectibles, and other specified assets are subject to specific rules under section 351(e)(1)(B). Look-thru rules apply if a nonbusiness entity holds a 10-percent interest in another entity. The look-thru rules apply to a nonbusiness entity holding a 10-percent interest in another entity, treating the entity as holding its ratable share of the assets. The amendments made by this section limit minority discounts for transfers of interests in entities, with no discount allowed if the transferee and family members have control of the entity. Effective for transfers after the enactment of this Act.
